Dear Ursula Ahart:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000832
Special Investigation Intake Date: July 1, 2025
License #: CB820201475
Licensee Group Organization: Federation of Youth Services
Licensee Designee: Ursula Ahart
Chief Administrator: Ursula Ahart
Agency Name: Transitional Living Program
Agency Address: 548 E GRAND BLVD
DETROIT, MI 48207-3534
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/20/2026
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
7/14/2025 Email Other
7/11/2025 Email Other
7/10/2025 Email Documentation received or sent
7/2/2025 Phone Interview
7/2/2025 Email Other
7/2/2025 Email Other
7/2/2025 Phone Interview
7/2/2025 Email Other
7/1/2025 Email Other
7/1/2025 Phone Special Investigation Initiation;
Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
Section • (2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
Description following areas:
1

• (k) Termination.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/25/25, a youth was brought to the hospital for seizure
activity. On 6/29/25, the youth was medically cleared for
discharge and the agency would not bring her back to the facility.
The agency submitted a removal request on 6/29/25, but they are
required to give a 30-day notice.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Hospital Social Worker was interviewed by phone on 7/1/2025.
She reported Youth A was brought to Children’s Hospital on
6/25/2025 by staff of Transitional Living Program due to seizure-
like activity. After a few days of medical testing, it was determined
there was no physical reason for the seizures, rather it was related
to stress and the youth’s trauma history. Youth A was cleared for
discharge on 6/29/2025 with a recommendation for outpatient
services. Hospital Social Worker stated she had heard staff of
Transitional Living Program were refusing to take Youth A back to
her placement, so she spoke with Foster Care Supervisor who
was at Youth A’s bedside. Foster Care Supervisor told Hospital
Social Worker that Transitional Living Program would not be
taking Youth A back to her placement due to Youth A having
demonstrated self-harm behaviors prior to the hospitalization.
Hospital Social Worker stated MDHHS staff “worked quickly” and
located a placement for Youth A to whom Youth A was discharged
on 6/30/2025.
Hospital Social Worker stated she has previously worked in child
welfare and knows Transitional Living Program must give 30-day
notice and cannot refuse to bring a child back to the facility. It was
explained to Hospital Social Worker that Transitional Living
Program’s Tillman House is an independent living home run by a
child placing agency after which she stated she thought it was a
child caring institution (CCI) so believed CCI contract
requirements applied to Youth A.
Executive Director responded to an email informing her of the
allegations on 7/1/2025 by stating Youth A was placed into Tillman
House after she was referred to the program by MDHHS staff.
Since that time, Youth A has been hospitalized twice during which
information was gained making it clear Youth A was not
appropriate for placement in the agency’s independent living
home. Executive Director expressed concerns with Youth A’s
seizures, as the home is not staffed around the clock, so there
won’t always be someone around to ensure Youth A’s safety
2

when the seizures occur. Executive Director reported Youth A’s
local MDHHS office took over case management and were
working on placing Youth A back into a previous foster home on
6/30/2025.
Foster Care Worker 1, the Transitional Living Program foster
care worker assigned to Youth A’s case prior to her program
termination, responded to an email request for an interview on
7/2/2025 stating he was on vacation adding he was on vacation at
the time of Youth A’s hospitalization and program termination.
Foster Care Worker 2, the MDHHS worker assigned to Youth A
prior to her placement in Tillman House, was interviewed by
phone on 7/2/2025. She reported Youth A was referred to
Transitional Living Program by a different MDHHS staff at the time
of removal from her parental home. Youth A was subsequently
placed in a Transitional Placement Program (TPP) foster home
while Transitional Living Program was considering Youth A for
placement, at which time MDHHS Worker was assigned as Youth
A’s assigned Foster Care Worker. During that time, Youth A had
seizures at school on two different occasions for which she went
to the hospital but was not admitted. Foster Care Worker 2 stated
Youth A was not given a diagnosis after either hospital visit. She
stated, she attended a well-child visit with Youth A during which
Youth A reported suffering a concussion prior to entering foster
care. Foster Care Worker 2 stated a referral was made for Youth
A to see a neurologist, but the referral expired so it has not yet
happened. She reported Youth A was accepted into Transitional
Living Program’s Tillman House on 6/12/2025. Foster Care
Worker 2 stated she did not inform Transitional Living Program
staff of the concussion history, the referral to a neurologist, or the
seizures that had occurred while she was Youth A’s assigned
foster care worker.
Foster Care Worker 2 reported after Youth A moved into Tillman
House, she experienced another seizure, went to the hospital and
was discharged without a diagnosis. Youth A was again
hospitalized for a seizure on 6/25/2025 and was diagnosed with
Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES,) which is related to
her mental health. Foster Care Worker 2 reported Executive
Director sent an email to the local office MDHHS Director, BSC
Director, and multiple other MDHHS staff indicating Transitional
Living Program would not be willing to take Youth A back to
Tillman House because they were not equipped to provide for
Youth A’s mental health issues. She stated she believed Foster
Care Worker 1 was still assigned to Youth A’s case in MiSACWIS,
3

but Foster Care Worker 2 took over locating a new placement for
Youth A when Youth A was ready for discharge from the hospital.
Foster Care Worker 2 was able to get Youth A placed back into
her previous TPP home on 6/30/2025.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed by phone on 7/2/2025.
She stated she completed the intake of Youth A into Transitional
Living Program’s Tillman House on 6/12/2025 during which Foster
Care Worker 2 was present with Youth A. Foster Care Supervisor
stated, a few days after intake, Youth A told agency staff she had
a history of concussion and was supposed to see a neurologist .
Foster Care Supervisor contacted Foster Care Worker 2 as she
had not told Foster Care Supervisor this information during intake.
Foster Care Worker 2 told Foster Care Supervisor a referral to a
neurologist had been made, but there had not yet been an
appointment scheduled.
Foster Care Supervisor reported on 6/19/2025, Youth A was taken
to the hospital for seizure-like symptoms while at Tillman House
and was released after being treated for a migraine. Foster Care
Supervisor reached out to Foster Care Worker 2 expressing
concern with not having been provided with information about
Youth A’s medical concerns/needs. On 6/25/2025, Youth A again
demonstrated seizure-like activity at Tillman House and was taken
to the hospital after which she was admitted for testing and
treatment. Foster Care Supervisor reported Foster Care Worker 1
reached out to her on the morning of 6/27/2025 while he was at
the hospital and told her he was concerned because Youth A
couldn’t identify herself or Foster Care Worker 1. Foster Care
Supervisor went to the hospital to stay with Youth A. She stated
Youth A had a bedside commode as she was unable to walk to
get to the bathroom. While Foster Care Supervisor was with her,
Youth A had another seizure. Foster Care Supervisor observed
Youth A shaking while non-responsive after which she went into a
catatonic-like state. Foster Care Supervisor stated hospital staff
took Youth A’s vitals then left the room stating she was safe, and
they just needed to let the episode pass. Hospital staff informed
Foster Care Supervisor they were diagnosing Youth A with PNES
which is a psychological disorder. She stated they told her there
was no way to know when the seizures would occur, how frequent
they would occur, or what the severity could be. Foster Care
Worker 1 sent an email the same day to Foster Care Worker 2
with a copy to Foster Care Supervisor, Foster Care Worker 2’s
Supervisor and other local office leadership informing them of
Youth A’s condition and the agency’s request for Foster Care
Worker 2 to locate a new placement for Youth A as Tillman House
4

did not seem appropriate based on her condition and needs.
Foster Care Supervisor stated Hospital Staff told her Youth A was
ready to be discharged with medication and a referral to
Community Mental Health services. Since a psychotropic
medication consent form would need to be signed before Youth A
could be given the prescribed medication, Foster Care Worker 2
began working on obtaining those signatures
On the following Monday, 6/30/2025, Foster Care Supervisor was
at the hospital with Youth A who was still wobbly when trying to
walk and needed assistance to the bathroom. Foster Care
Supervisor was present when Youth A met with a psychologist
who asked Youth A when she last self-harmed, to which she
responded, 6/5/2025. Youth A stated she told Foster Care Worker
2 about this self-harming attempt. Foster Care Supervisor stated
she told the psychologist she was not comfortable with Youth A
coming back to Tillman House as the home is not staffed around
the clock and Youth A could come and go as she pleased, so
there might not be someone around if she had another seizure or
attempted self-harm. Additionally, Foster Care Supervisor
expressed her concern that the local CMH is taking 4-6 weeks to
see youths and, even when an appointment was made, Youth A
could refuse to participate. The psychologist told Foster Care
Supervisor he would talk with Hospital Social Worker.
On 6/30/2025 Foster Care Worker obtained Youth A’s father’s
signature on the psychotropic medication consent form, so Youth
A was discharged with medication. Foster Care Supervisor
reported Foster Care Worker 2 had secured a placement with
Youth A’s previous caregiver to whom she was discharged. Foster
Care Worker 1 took over case management responsibility that
day; however, the change had not yet been made in the child’s
record.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Tillman House Supportive Housing Program Statement which
includes the following regarding termination of
services/discharge:
• If the youth is discharged, or the foster care case is closed,
the assigned foster care worker will work with the assigned
MDHHS worker to ensure the youth is provided with
placement options appropriate to the youth’s level of
independence.
• Prior to the youth’s case being closed, agency staff will
work to secure appropriate housing for the youth.
5

Emails forwarded by Foster Care Supervisor:
• 6/16/2025 Foster Care Supervisor to Foster Care Worker 2
stating Youth A reported having suffered a concussion in
the past and that she was experiencing ongoing headaches
for which she was supposed to see neurologist. Foster
Care Supervisor requested details regarding Youth A’s
medical and neurological needs.
• 6/16/2025 Foster Care Worker 2 to Foster Care Supervisor
stating there was a referral to neurology.
• 6/19/2025 from Foster Care Supervisor to Foster Care
Worker 2 informing her Youth A had been taken to the
hospital by ambulance for a possible seizure.
• 6/20/2025 from Foster Care Supervisor to Foster Care
Worker 2 stating Youth A was treated for migraine and
released from the hospital. She expressed her concern
about not having been provided with any information about
a concussion or history of seizures.
• 6/27/2025 from Foster Care Worker 1 to Foster Care
Worker 2 stating he was at the hospital with Youth A who
was scheduled to see a psychiatrist for a mental health
evaluation as she was not presenting any medical health
concerns. Foster Care 1 described Youth A’s condition and
requested MDHHS begin seeking a new placement for
Youth A stating she may require a more structured and
supportive placement with a focus on mental health, which
Transitional Living Program could not provide.
Social Work Contact in Youth A’s case record:
• 6/4/2025 by Foster Care Worker 2 documenting she
attended a well-child appointment with Youth A during
which the physician recommended Youth A be referred to
psychology and neurology due to depression, PTSD, and
post-concussion symptoms.
Incident Report in Youth A’s case record:
• 6/19/2025 by Foster Care Worker 1 documenting that, at
9:10 PM, Youth A went to the staff office stating she did not
feel well and reported a history of seizures. A call was
made to Emergency Medical Services as Youth A’s speech
6

became slurred prior to her closing her eyes and becoming
unresponsive.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as they followed their written
process when working with the youth’s MDHHS Worker to secure
appropriate placement upon determining the youth was not
appropriate for the agency’s independent living home after
discovering mental health and neurological needs not disclosed to
the agency during the referral/acceptance process.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
July 14, 2025
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 16, 2025

Area Manager
